text:
Broadway, west side, north from, but not including West 40th Street, showing the Broadway Theatre, at the S.W. corner of West 41st Street.

About 1902.

New York Edison Co.

1422-1432 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of West 40th Street. The view shows the Empire Theatre, adjoining the S.E. corner, with Browne's Chop House on the south.

About 1905.

Brown Brothers.

1432, 1426 and 1424 Broadway, at adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of West 40th Street, showing the Empire Theatre at No. 1426. This enterprise opened January 25, 1893. Adjacent to same is Browne's Chop House, a similar famous spot in this former theatrical district. On the left appears an extensive view eastward on the south side of 40th Street and upon which, at the rear of the Theatre is the 25-storied Worlds Tower Building.

About 1918.

Gift of Gilbert Miller.

1432, 1426 and 1424 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of West 40th Street (left), showing the Empire Theatre at No. 1426 and Browne's Chop House at No. 1424. This is a negative copy of a photograph.

About 1918.

Gift of Gilbert Miller.

Broadway, east side, north from, but not including, 40th Street. In the centre, on the S.E. corner of 41st Street, the Hotel Continental may be seen, two years before its destruction. May 5, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway (center), from W. 40th (right intersection) to 41st (left) Streets, as viewed southeastward from the Chandler Building at No. 220 W. 42nd Street. The photographer shows at the N.E. corner of 40th Street, the 27 storied Central National Bank Building occupying the site of the former Holland Building. Under demolition is the Broadway Theatre, which occupied the frontage on the south side of 41st Street, extending from Seventh Avenue (foreground) to Broadway. Its main entrance was upon the latter. Here was erected the 33 storied structure known as 1441 Broadway. Subsequently the Continental Hotel (with billboard sign atop thereof) and the 3 story adjacent structure were razed for the site of the present 40 storied, No. 1450 Broadway Building. Indistinctly in the left background appears the vague outline of the 10 E. 40th Street Building.

P.L. Sperr
February 5, 1929.

(1)
Broadway, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of 40th Street, seen from the roof of the Metropolitan Opera House.
February 20, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from the street level. The Empire Theatre is the building adjoining the corner.
May 10, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broadway, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of 40th Street, seen from the roof of the Metropolitan Opera House.
February 20, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from the street level. The Empire Theatre is the building adjoining the corner.
May 10, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, east side, from, but not including, 40th Street, to and including 42nd Street. In the centre, may be seen the Hotel Continental, on which demolition work has just begun.
February 20, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
